facts.text: Sadhu Ram was killed on the 5th of November, 1953, at about 6-45 P.M. at the shop of Vas Dev P.W. 2.
The appellant along with others assaulted Sadhu Ram. The appellant was armed with a takwa.

Numerous injuries were found on the person of Sadhu Ram. According to the doctor, who held the postmortem examination, injuries 1, 3 and 4 were due to a heavy sharp edged weapon and could be caused by a takwa.
It was denied by the prosecution that the deceased was assaulted by any other person with a takwa.
According to the Medical evidence, injuries 1, 3 and 4 individually, as well as collectively, were enough to cause death in the ordinary course of nature.
In the Court of Sessions the appellant along with others was charged under section 148 and section 302, read with section 149 of the Indian Penal Code.

The Additional Sessions Judge held that the charge of rioting was not proved. He accordingly found the appellant and three others guilty under section 302 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code. He acquitted the other three accused.

There was an appeal by three convicted persons to the High Court and the High Court convicted the appellant alone under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code, confirming the sentence of death but altered the conviction of the other accused from section 302/34 to section 323, Indian Penal Code. It held that the provisions of section 34 of the Indian Penal Code did not apply.
Vas Dev P.W. 2 had admitted that Mitu took away the takwa from the appellant after Sadhu Ram had been dragged out of the shop but no takwa blow was given outside the shop.
Prakash Chand P.W. 4, another eye-witness, also admitted that Mitu had taken the takwa from the appellant when they had come out of the shop.
With reference to injury No. 1 the doctor stated that the wounds were not very clean-cut. The other incised injuries on the head were bone deep. The bone, however, had not been cut.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant could legally be convicted for murder and sentenced under section 302, Indian Penal Code when he was not charged with that offence, after acquittal of rioting (s.148) and offence under s.302/149.
Whether section 149 of the Indian Penal Code creates a specific offence distinct from the substantive offence under s.302.
Whether sections 236 and 237 of the Code of Criminal Procedure apply to permit conviction under s.302 without a specific charge.

petitioner_arguments.text: As the appellant had been acquitted of the charge of rioting and the offence under section 302/149, he could not be convicted for the substantive offence of murder under section 302 without a charge having been framed against him under that section.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 233, 234, 235, 236, 237, 239 CrPC; Barendra Kumar Ghosh v. Emperor; Panchu Das v. Emperor; Reazuddi v. King-Emperor; Emperor v. Madan Mandal

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 149 creates a specific offence separate from s.302.
Appellant was prejudiced in defence by absence of specific charge under s.302, as he might have cross-examined doctor and witnesses more closely on injuries and takwa use.

respondent_arguments.text: Section 149 did not create any offence at all and therefore no separate charge was obligatory under section 233 CrPC; provisions of sections 236 and 237 CrPC apply.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 236, 237 CrPC; Theetkumalai Gounder v. King-Emperor; Queen Empress v. Bisheshar

respondent_arguments.text: Section 149 merely provides for constructive guilt similar to section 34 IPC.

court_reasoning.text: Section 149 IPC creates a specific offence distinct from s.34, as it makes members of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed by one member in prosecution of common object, even without common intention or overt act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clear distinction between s.34 (common intention) and s.149 (membership in unlawful assembly).

court_reasoning.text: A person charged under s.302/149 cannot be convicted of substantive s.302 without specific charge, as required by s.233 CrPC; Calcutta High Court view correct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Acquittal of rioting and s.302/149 means no conviction for substantive offence without charge.

court_reasoning.text: Sections 236/237 CrPC do not apply as no doubt about facts or which offence committed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts clearly establish murder if appellant's acts proved, no room for alternative charges.

court_reasoning.text: Absence of charge under s.302 is illegality, not mere irregularity curable under ss.535/537 CrPC; appellant prejudiced in defence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant not called upon to meet substantive murder charge, may not have concentrated defence accordingly.

holdings.text: Section 149 IPC creates a specific offence; conviction under substantive s.302 impermissible without specific charge after acquittal under s.302/149.
Sections 236/237 CrPC inapplicable where facts clearly point to specific offence without doubt.

precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between ss.34 and 149 IPC; s.149 creates specific offence.
Cannot convict substantive offence without charge after acquittal under s.149.
Cannot convict substantive after charge under s.149.

precedents_cited.case_name: Emperor v. Madan Mandal and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports illegality of substantive conviction without charge post s.149 acquittal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Theetkumalai Gounder and Others v. King-Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.149 not offence but declaratory; disagreed as predates Barendra Kumar.

precedents_cited.case_name: Queen Empress v. Bisheshar and Others
Karnail Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Cannot convert 302/149 to 302/34 then to 302 without charge.

precedents_cited.case_name: Queen v. Sabid Ali and Others

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: s.149 creates specific offence of constructive liability for unlawful assembly offences; distinct from s.34 common intention; s.302 substantive murder.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires separate charge for distinct offences; ss.236/237 for doubt on offence; ss.535/537 cure irregularities but not failure of justice from absent charge.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court conviction under s.302 and death sentence set aside due to absence of specific charge under s.302, constituting illegality and prejudice to appellant's defence.

key_quotes.text: Section 149 of the Indian Penal Code creates a specific offence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing s.149 from s.34.

key_quotes.text: A person charged with an offence read with section 149 cannot be convicted of the substantive offence without a specific charge being framed as required by section 233 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Decides principal legal issue in favor of appellant.

key_quotes.text: It is difficult to hold in the circumstances of the present case that the appellant was not prejudiced by the non-framing of a charge under section 302, Indian Penal Code.
key_quotes.speaker: court
